title: Tactile Images for Teaching Lego to People with Visual Impairments

description.text: We created tactile images corresponding to lego pieces to help a student with visual impairment build the Lego Wedo kicker. lego tactle images can be put in a sorting tray with 8 slots corresponding to 8 slides in the Tiny Tap "Listen Feel Build" Instructions we created (see TinyTap app). Student can select pieces independently based on the feel of the image (together with a few braille stickers to indicate duplicates e.g., 2p, or the slot number) Then listen to instructions provided in the app. Instructions run 30 sec only and there are 4 clicks per slide to keep information simple. Go to http://tinytap.it and search "Listen Feel Build" Try it!

OK i know the servo horn assembly doesn't have the teeth that the servo horn has. The fact of the matter is most 3d printers won't be able to handle tiny details like that. So i opted to make it round. If it doesn't work a little bit of super glue should fix that. "Gear with Screw Drive":

This is the first design my daughter has made. I said to here, "How can you improve on that other design which has limitations?", and she came up with this. A modification on the first version. The first version of the Z-carriage had a couple of limitations. One was the fact that there is a limit to how big you can print the thing. If you're platform is only 100mm, then the maximum separation you could have had was 100mm. The other limitation is actually one of the interesting design points. It created a teater totter between the sliding rods and the opposing lead screw using the mounting rod as the fulcrum. Although interesting for easy balance and support, it limits the distance between the lead screw and the front face of the carriage. Bottom line, it's a nice design, but we came up with a better way. This thing is a carriage that is meant to ride along the z-axis. It has capture nuts on the bottom, and in the middle, so that it will ride up and down with the turning of the lead screw. It is printed in two identical pieces, which are flipped over and mated to each other with the central capture nut. It's a pretty beefy assembly, which takes a good part of an hour to print on my Up! printer at 0.25mm, Loose, Normal. It has to be beefy as it is the foundation of the cantilever clips: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5783 All combined, a couple of these pieces, plus the cantilever clips, and 3 nuts, makes for a very nice linear slide carriage. A further improvement would be to have some graphite infused bushings captured into the holes that slide along the smooth rods, but that's for another design. The piece of paper in the photos is the actual design sketch my daughter used to flesh out the idea. I thought it was kind of funny as we tried to draw in perspective.

1) Look at your design where you'd going to put a vertical linear slide.
2) Measure the center distance from the lead screw to the center of the mounting rod.
3) Measure the center distance from the lead screw out to the center of the sliding rods.
4) Use those measurements to alter the OpenScad file to suit your needs.
5) Print a couple of these pieces out
6) Use a heat gun, or some form of heat, to loosen up the holes for the capture nuts
7) Force the capture nuts into their holes.
Note: There is a mating nut between the two pieces. It is half the height of the nut. Press a nut into one half, flip the other piece over, and mate it to this nut. This serves to align and hold the two halves together.
8) Press is all together and thread it onto the leadscrew of your linear slide.
9) Slip the smooth rods into their proper places in the carriage, and into their proper places in the endoskeleton
10) Place a couple of cantilever clips over the verticals of the carriage
11) Rejoice! This is a nice conceptual design. In reality, it won't work optimally until there are captured bushings of some sort in the holes on the linear slides. Also, if you don't get the nut aligned nice and flat, it will cause binding which may either result in wobble, or simply make the lead screw too hard to turn. These are fairly big pieces, depending. You'll want to do your best to prevent warping, although the design is somewhat forgiving to warping on what starts out as the "bottom" of the pieces. Although the application here is for a vertical rise, the exact same pieces can be used for a horizontal carriage.

Have you ever tried to germinate seeds in your own private urban premises? If yes, you might remember the hassle with ugly brittle plastic pseudo-greenhouses and difficult to handle soil and pots. Here is the solution! A beautiful and sturdy desktop greenhouse with a highly convenient seedling handling system. It comes with a pot press for creating temporary soil packages made of newspaper. When the seelings are big enough, they can be easily taken out from the greenhouse and planted directly with the pot, as the paper will quickly decompose. 
The perfect thing for urban gardening, recycling and DIY!
Made by Alessandro @ Fab Lab Zurich

The plant pot press is 3D printed. Here it is done with wood PLA, but you can choose any material you like. When finished, you can use 7 Ã— 20 cm strips of newspaper to create your little temporary pots that are then filled with soil. Find the .stl file attached.
The pot receptacle and the drip mat are cnc milled from foam material. It is not ideal as it is very, very soft â€“ but it is waterproof! Find the 2D design in the attached .dxf file together with the depth profile for 2,5-axis milling.
The foam parts are held together by a wooden skirt made of lasered 3 mm plywood. It is attached to the pot receptacle with two-sided adhesive tape. The skirt overlaps the drip mat and holds the two parts together. The lateral grip sections let you choose to pick up only the pot receptacle or the whole greenhouse.
The glass cover is lasered from 3 mm plexiglass. No glue is needed, as the teeth hold rather tight. If you try to do it yourself, watch out for your laser cut thickness and make tests before lasering the whole thing or the teeth might not fit.
Finally the little red pot holding devices are lasered from perspex and assembled. Also here, no glue is needed. For more stability we have added a perspex base to the drip mat. It is attached with two-sided adhesive tape.
Find all lasercut shapes in the attached .dxf file. Happy gardening!

You have to make it to silicone though. I have no idea how. you need a make a silicone mold i suppose and prepare that with vaseline and cast it with silicone again.
I have made a very similar version "manually" (yes, by hand) out of the silicone dental labs use and that works very very well. You also need the Behringer C-2 stereo microphone set. those (should) fit into the holes tightly. Or any other microphone with a diameter of 20mm.
Have fun.

author: omid80

description.text: My own custom-made midi controller that can be redesigned easily

A custom modular midi-box.
The lid stacks (think: lego) into the bottom-part of the main module in a way so the faceplate tilts slightly towards the user.
It's sturdy, modular and can be stowed away easily since it's a box.
The Faceplate is a simple laser-cut, so you can easily change the innards and make a new custom arrangement of your parts. After filing of some of the edges it stacks quite nicely. The idea is based on the awesome!!! instructible by fuzzywobble and uses an arduino-clone (teensy) to generate the midi-messages for your computer: http://www.instructables.com/id/A-Framework-For-Making-Affordable-Stylish-Modula/ This thing was made by CNC'ing MDF... A really stupid idea unless you feel the sudden urge to reverse the MDF-creation process and are in desperate need of a dust-machine (asthma included).

After buying a new belt for my Replicator2 and calibrating the motor to the max my belt were still too lose and clicking because of the slipping. So I took inspiration from funkshin XIDLER (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:135314) and built this idler. Simple to print and easy to source the parts needed for it. After installing it on my replicator2 I have no more clicking and smooth x-axis motion.

Print all parts with shell of 2, layer height .20 mm and infill of 10%. B.O.M.
1x M5x10mm flat head hex screw. You can use a a normal M5 hex screw here as well.
1x MR625-ZZ
1x M5 nut
1x M3 nut
1x M3x20mm hex screw Assemble on your replicator and enjoy the lack of clicking for a while. Or at least until you really need to replace your x-axis belt again.

this adapter should slide right into parts B10, B11, F2, and F3.

I was thinking that this might also work with an xacto knife if you mounted it in a thrust bearing. we will see.
Print part 4 times and assemble as demonstrated in crude included sketch. LOL

This is a mashup of Benjamin's Stencil-o-matic http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:55821 and Makerbot's Customizable iPhone Case http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:40703 to create an iPhone case with any imagery you like. First step is Benjamin's Stencil Factory http://chaaawa.com/stencil_factory. Then "Open in Customizer" and paste in "input", adjust the other case settings, and you're ready to print!

June 18 update: Finally got the fit right for iPhone 5, as well as some improvement for iPhone 4/4S. Woot! Thanks to everyone who helped figure this out. June 15 update: Added a new version of the mashup that puts your image inside one of the base shapes in the geometric pattern, and fixed a few bugs in the code. May 29 update: New features added, notably a "mashup" that uses both stencil and geometric together for a cool new effect. April 24 update: New version added with improved fit for the 4/4S and a taper feature to allow you to taper the walls of your case, improving grip. Also opening up all iphone size variables for tweaks. A number of smaller improvements are also included. March 16 Update: Couple of changes in this version:
  • Integrated the code from Makerbot's geometric customizable cases here, so you can choose what type of case to generate.
  • Further tweaks on the phone sizing - should now fit better on iPhone 5
    • The first step is Benjamin's Stencil Factory http://chaaawa.com/stencil_factory - detailed instructions are below. Once you have the output of Stencil Factory ready, open this thing in Customizer and copy the output of Stencil Factory into the "Input" field. Next, use the customizer parameters to select the correct phone model (iPhone 4/4s vs. iPhone 5), the case thickness, and any scale / position changes you want for your image. Click save to STL and you're ready to print! Note: The case tolerance field should only be adjusted if you've already printed and need to make fine adjustments.

The following instructions are copied directly from Benjamin's Stencil-o-Matic: 1. Open the Stencil Factory and select your image (gif, png, jpg). "Convert & copy", as its name suggests, also copies the output in your clipboard, so:
2. "Open in Customizer" and paste in "input".
3. "create STL", download and print. Stencil Factory also available in .zip (with sources) for offline use.

Hayden, is it too small or too big? If too small, try adjusting the tolerances on the Phone dimensions tab:
5 Perimeter Tolerance: Defaults to 0.5, maybe try it at 1 mm? That might be too big, but you can tweak
5 Height Tolerance: Defaults to 0.2, I'd try 0.5 and see how it works. Hard to say exactly what you need without seeing the print, but that's a starting point if it's too small.

comments.text:
Hey James, not sure if you saw the message I sent back to you - but my guess is that the text you have in paint is creating a very complex geometry that's overwhelming openSCAD's rendering engine. Since text has so many intricate details, it can be pretty complicated and create a lot of triangles, which eventually will cause openSCAD to give up.
The good news is that, if this is what's happening, the problem should only apply to the preview, not to the final output. Have you tried generating an output from customizer?
If you are able to post the jpg you're using - you could upload it as a "made" thing here, or post in dropbox or something - I can see if I get a different result on my end.

comments.text: Not sure about others - I've tested and used in IE and Chrome on windows and Chrome on osx.  Most of the people who have had the blank rectangle issue in the past actually had an issue with the image they were using - if the image you have creates an island in the middle of a rectangle, openSCAD will drop that island out, thus creating a blank rectangle.  Try inverting the colors in Benjamin's stencil factory interface (there's an option for this) or adding "bridges" in an image editing program.

comments.text: Wondering if you have "unsupported islands in your image" - i.e. details that would be left behind on the build plate after printing due to lack of connection to other parts.  For instance, the letter "O", unedited, would turn out as a circle instead of an O, since the middle is not connected.  To resolve this, you can add bridges in any imaging program, or even inside Benjamin's code (there are buttons at the bottom to draw bridges freehand).

title: Rudolf Reigns
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Rudolf takes Santa on a wild ride. Video of prototype is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J9DfzWMzZoI&list=UUv_zm49u-RjnCJVwhUO-ecA Designed using Sketchup Make 2015, and printed in PLA on a Makerbot Replicator 2 using Makerware 2.3.3.42 "Standard" (.2mm layer height, 2 shells, 10% infill) settings.

Study "Assembly.skp".  
Print all pieces as shown in "Assembly.skp".   
Test fit and trim, file, sand, etc. all parts as necessary for smooth movement of moving surfaces, and tight fit for non moving surfaces. Depending on the colors you chose and your printer settings, more or less trimming, filing and/or sanding will be required.  
Assemble as per "Assembly.skp", paying close attention to the gear and eccentric alignment.  When installing each "Gear.stl" into "Base.stl", carefully pry apart the gear block tower to slide the gear in place, again, paying close attention to the gear alignment as indicated in "Assembly.skp". It is best to start at either end, then install the gears toward the opposite end.  
Lubricate moving surfaces with light machine oil.  
Comment if questions.  
Hope you like it!

title: Olaf from Frozen - Snowflake Christmas Ornament

description.text: Anthony Herrera delivers again. This year, in addition to his excellent Star Wars snowflakes, he's got a series of snowflakes inspired by the movie Frozen: http://www.anthonyherreradesigns.com/index.php/8-ahd-blog/15-frozen-snowflakes I figured I'd take a crack at converting the PDFs into STLs because I'm better at 3D printing than I am at folding and cutting paper. And I figured I'd start with Olaf because I know someone that lives at my house that will love him... :-D

Instructions to make one:  Download and print.  
What I did to create the model:  
Download PDF from anthonyherreradesigns.com, open PDF in graphics program, remove the guides for folding, mirror the paths that make up Olaf, copy & rotate 5 times to make a complete snowflake, clean up paths, export as DXF, import DXF into OpenSCAD, linear extrude, add a loop so it can be hung up easily, export as STL.

description.text: This is a mashup of Patrick Prosic's ActionCar STL (thing:249) as a shell to fit over a standard pinewood derby block.  The wheelbase is shorter than the standard cuts made on the block in the official pinewood derby kit, so one of the axle slots on the wood block will need to be re-cut.  Other than that, the wood block requires only a few straight saw cuts to fit the shell.  All dimensions are legal according to official pinewood derby rules.

Print with support structures underneath.  One of the photos shows the underside of the piece with honeycomb support at 7mm spacing.  It looked difficult to remove but turned out to be surprisingly easy.  An OpenSCAD file is included with the downloads, but requires the STL file from thing:249.  Otherwise, just download and print the STL.

comments.text: This year the official rules prohibit the use of mercury, lead shot, or anything else that is loose inside the body.  The full plastic shell is in full compliance with the official rules, although, as you mention, individual troops can apply their own rules as they see fit.  As it is, a lot of weight is in the shell, and it is not optimally distributed for the best speed.  But it will be a great looking car!
comments.author: TimEdwards

comments.text: I remember when I was a cub scout. There was big controversy if certain ppl in the troop were using mercury as a weight. The idea is that the mercury shifts as it hits the bottom of the ramp, giving it an extra oomph of propulsion.

author: Logistas

description.text:
This is my contest entry for FirstBuild's Icebox Challenge!  
With small refrigerators, it is common to have difficulty fitting everything you want into the available space. Usually, the problem is with horizontal space; there is plenty of vertical space to use, if only you could stack your groceries! And the cartons that eggs come in are far too wide to fit in your refrigerator!  
However, with the Universal Stacking Egg Carton, that won't be a problem any more! You can stack your eggs as high as you want. If you have multiple sizes of eggs, you can sort them by layer without having to rescale the print for each size. And if you want a different layout for your egg container, you can use the interlocking pieces to make pretty much whatever layout you want!

I am familiar with the differences between and limitations of different printers. For that reason, the basic 2X2 and 2X3 blocks can be printed without support and with loose or tight tolerances. These blocks also use less plastic than the interlocking pieces. The interlocking pieces are the same for each version, except that the size of the gap for the insertion blocks ranges between 5 and 7 mm thick (if your printer has tighter tolerances, use the Tight piece; if you do not know about your printer's capabilities, print the Test Plate first). The plates are simply a set of four pieces of the specified tolerance. The Test plate is one of each tolerance piece, which can be tested with each other to determine the optimum gap for your printer. The pieces should be tight-fitting so that they do not fall apart when used in stacks. I suggest filing the protruding blocks (5 mm thick) to fit inside of the gap after printing.

Just loved the shape of this rocket. It turned out to be a great way to tune the speed and temperature of your printer to a batch of filament.  
Printed in vase mode watch the print progress if you get little blobs forming on the inside of the model then you most lightly have the temperature too high or are over extruding or going too slow. If you have gaps and the model does not hold together then too cool too fast or under extruding.  
Now go build you Inter ballistic strike force
Printed with PLA at .3 in vase mode. If your slicer does not do this then I have included a Makerbot x3g file if you are using a Makerbot.

Holder for electric toothbrush heads (e.g. Oral-B) with customizable thickness and count.
Individual holders are extra objects to be printed with different colors, matching the heads' color ring. The Customizr seems to break this, so I deactivated it for now. Please use OpenSCAD or ask me directly if you need a custom version

For three Oral-B heads simply use the provided stl-files and skip to printing. For more/less heads or thicker/thinner heads use the openscad file and change the variables as needed.
Export the individual objects to different stl files or later divide the objects in cura.

Print the base in one color (e.g. white), then print multiple single holders in different colors, matching the brush heads' color coding.  
After assembling you can optionally weld the holders to the base plate using a hot needle or a piece of wire wrapped around a soldering iron.

description.text: Something I made in my DDP class today, using Rhino for the first time. Not very good design but it's possible to print.

Do you want a plant at your desk but are housed in a cubicle farm without any hope of UV light?  Or are you one of those people who can kill un-killable plants? Then "grow" your own "Modular Customizable Desk Plant"!  It will always be in bloom (if you want it to be), it will always be green (if you want it to be), and it never ever ever wants water or sunshine.  
Just be sure to put it in some soil or rocks or the poor thing might grow so big it tips over!

Requires Printing with Support It's easy:
1) Print out the pieces you want your plant to possess
2) Snap everything together
3) Don't forget to put it into a pot with soil! The awesome Rose is courtesy of ProCoPrint3D If you have your own ends you wish to attach to your plant, use the Connection Pin extra or just modify the Solidworks files available in the SW_Parts.zip

This is a custom micro quad frame.
It is the combination of the Zippin SpeederBike and the DreamCatcher.
It flies like a bike and crashes like a dream.
Here is some action footage: http://youtu.be/2tWLE1si2Os

We suggest to print this file with high-impact ABS filament:
http://store.3dprintingsystems.com/1.75m_ABS_Filament_Crystal
Om a UP! Plus 2 printer, it works great on 240?C with slow print speed and 0.15mm resolution. To complete the build, you need 8.5mm coreless motors with propellers, a brushed flight controller and a 500mah battery (ideally 20x45mm, like the Hubsan X4 packs). You can get suitable motors and flight controllers here:
http://micro-motor-warehouse.com/collections/8mm-custom-builds

comments.text: Ok, I've got it printed. I noticed it looks like you have two motors facing downward? I would guess this is to allow for longer props. Could you describe your setup and which directions the motors are spinning? I can't discern from the video.
comments.author: MicroMotorWarehouse

comments.text:
I use four motors of the same direction. I turn two upside down, so the props clear, yes. If you turn a CW motor upside down, it becomes a CCW motor. You will also have to reverse the prop for that. Some props have holes all the way through. If not, I cut the top off with a dremel.
Hope that helps. Ask if not!

description.text: This is designed to store a chess set in an attractive way. The pieces are arranged in a spiral set of shelves. You will need to scale it suit your needs - I think the STL file comes in quite small. This is designed to match the square chess set size at this link: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:34017

This does not require supports or rafts. The example is printed out at a height, width and length of 150mm. The example in the photos was printed with a Rep 2, so slightly larger than the max size in the Makerware software but it still prints fine except for some stringy artifacts on the top shelf. Not sure what is happening there.
Update: I figured out the problem with the top of the print it doesn't have time to cool because the part suddenly becomes smaller. I have since switched to Simplify3D - this program allows smaller parts to be done slower allowing for proper cooling. I also use a a regular house fan once the prints get to the small parts - that helps as well. You will need to resize to suit your needs - I think the STL file comes in quite small.

Simple coaster with Green Bay Packers logo etched in.

Designed coaster using 123D design then took Green Bay logo and etched it out in center.  
In order to make multicolor, I watched the print in Pronterface and when it started the layer with the base of the inner etching, I paused it, changed colors and resumed. Once it completed the base of the etching and the first row above it (noted by seeing the outline of the etching), I paused again and changed back to the original color and resumed.

title: iPhone 6 PLUS Spotter / Scope / Binocular Mount

description.text:
Update
Now modified, test fit and printed over my 6plus.
Requires rotating before printing (one day i'll figure out how to rotate the .stl) and the eyepiece needs support - see my pic for a working method.
Screen images are simulated, its night time and I didn't fancy pointing my rifle out the window to get a scope pic :) Apologies for anyone who downloaded the original model to find the fit was less than great. if you need a different diameter eyepiece - leave a comment and ill upload one to suit based from the Outside Diameter you give
Description
Wanted a way to use my iPhone's camera to look through my spotter scope so I don't have to move once taking my shot at the paper target. The design was inspired by whiteboardwarriors2's design for an iPhone 4s. I guess it could also be mounted directly to a telescopic rifle scope; but unless it's an air rifle or .22 rimfire, I wouldn't recommend it due to recoil. The case part was intended to also accommodate a thin (1.2mm extra) case all the way around. But should hold a case-less phone in much the same level (for the lens centre) as the genuine cases don't wrap around the bottom.
Also has access for a charger should your battery start getting low.

Print one of the cases out on its back and an eyepiece to match the outside diameter of your scope's eyepiece then push together to assemble with a blob of your favourite sticky stuff. There is a little bit of extra room inside the cup to be as gentle as possible on your scope, but feel free to plastidip as whiteboardwarriors2 did on theirs i remixed from. Nice idea.  
There is a little notch on the back of the eye-cup to help locate the cup to the case on 55mm cups+. In some cases - glue may not be necessary. Also complies with Apple's recommended "keep-out" zone for the field of view on the lens; taken from their official drawings.

title: Dennerle Nano Cube 10l fish tank lamp stand repair part.

description.text: I've got small Dennerle Nano Cube 10l fish tank. One day it's lamp stand has broken. I've developed a model to repair it.

You need:
  • 1 x printed part
  • 1 x broken lamp stand
  • 3 x M3x14 screws (M3x12 also suitable)
  • 3 x M3 wide washers (DIN9021)
  • 3 x M3 nuts
    • How to made and fit to place:
  • Remove plastic screw from lamp stand.
  • Put nuts to slots.
  • Screw broken stand to new support block.
  • Put it on place back.
    • This block is 3 mm thick and so it doesn't fit the old lamp support
    place. I don't want to do it thinner for strength reasons. To fit this block on place one rounded support corner moved to back side and one removed out.
    I prefer to put hex nuts to slots with significant force. If you don't - customize OpenSCAD file.

Yes

Yes

0.2 mm

Infill:

25-50

If the middle finger peg breaks too easily you might want to reprint it at a higher infill or increase your shell count.

title: UK Royal Shield of Arms Coin Display Holder

description.text: In 2008 the general circulation coins of the United Kingdom were changed for a puzzle design.  These coins was created by Matt Dent after a public competition. He created a design based on the Royal Shield of Arms, but few people realize that you can piece together the complete shield design as seen on the £1 coin using the other coins in the series. The major design feature was the introduction of a reverse design shared across six coins (1p, 2p, 5p, 10p, 20p, 50p), that can be pieced together to form an image of the Royal Shield. This was the first time a coin design had been featured across multiple coins in this way.  Upon returning from my trip to England and Wales, I wanted to display my UK coins as designed as the puzzle and thus the coin holder was designed and 3D printed. My coins fit nice and tight.

Download the .stl file and 3D print.  Obtain the six United Kingdom coins and place together to form the Royal Shield of Arms.  The coins should be places from top left in a clockwise direction, 10p, 2p, 20p, 50p, and 1p.  The 5p is placed in the center.

title: Ultimaker Fab Feet w/ Rubber Grips

description.text: These BIG Ultimaker Feet by thingster appeared to be a well-made design, accommodated the cables nicely underneath and allowed for inserting a screw to hold them in place (drilling into the side of the Ultimaker required, of course).  However, I wanted something to grip the table top at least a little bit.  I added four posts underneath to hold small rubber feet (standard size found at Home Depot, etc.).  These feet will lift the Ultimaker Original 3.5 cm  (approx 1-3/8") off the surface - with the rubber feet installed.  Enjoy!

I printed this using high quality print settings.  I figured since they were the feet to my printer, best to give them strength.  It is probably overkill, but alas, it is done.  The rubber feet I used are just generic rubber feet you would get in the store to put under anything sitting on the countertops, shelves, to keep it from moving.  These measured 13mm across and fit perfectly inset into the groove.  If you first think it does not fit, it does.  Push one side of the rubber foot all the way up against the inner rim of one of the posts.  Press firmly and follow around until you met up and one point that may still be protruding.  Gently push the protrusion inward and press the foot downward.  This is a very precise match.  It's like I made it that way!  :)

I wanted to attach a bullet-style Space Pen to something, and decided having a cap that would fit the pen would be ideal. As a first step, I've modeled a replacement cap.  
The original cap's inner diameter is 9.3mm, but when I printed a cap at that size the inner diameter was 0.15mm too small. So I made this one 9.45 mm ID, and it fits just right.  
The shape could be tweaked to more closely resemble the original, with increased tapering, but I don't really require that at the moment and was more concerned that it would fit the pen full length.
Print with 0.4mm trace width to print the barrel with exactly two outlines. The tip is solid with a bridgeable bottom so it can be printed without support, but some infill is necessary.

description.text: Relocates the Keypad to a more usable angle! After installing the keypad and sd reader board onto the bezel using the original hardware and four fiber washers per screw to space it back for the SD card slot install the button trim to finish it off and hide the screw heads. I just glued on the trim piece with a dab of super glue in each corner. description.text: A simple yet sturdy coat hanger with two hooks to attach to a door (46mm thick). Note that you won't be able to close the door with that on.. mine is forever opened so that is not an issue !

I never really liked the M2 rubber corner pieces, so I designed these to actually hold down my glass and heated bed solidly without it lifting on me.  
Obviously the glass isn't quickly removed, but that's not something I do on a regular basis anyway.  Also, it is possible for the head to crash into these, but I've never had a problem.

Print with 50%+ infill, no support needed. 1x m2_glass_holder_left_front.stl
3x m2_glass_holder_all_other.stl. Really the left front is just to ensure things are square. You can't actually use the "all_other" one for the front left because the head will crash into it on homing. I'm pretty sure I used all the original bolts from the corners. Also, remove the middle piece of rubber (that is cut to square the glass) and place these pieces on top of the full corner rubber pad.

comments.text: These worked, thanks.

You need for each side:
2 10x10x160mm

title: Christmas Star - For the top of your Christmas Tree!

description.text:
3D printed star for the top of a Christmas Tree.   
Print with natural or translucent PLA for a sparkly look... great finishing touch to your Christmas Tree!  
There is a hole in the base of the star that sits onto the top of most Christmas Trees making it quick and easy to fit and remove.   
Includes designed in support (Refer instructions).

Print with Raft, 3 shells and 15% infill. Standard size is 75mm tall but can be scaled to suit.   
Carefully cut designed in support away from lower tips of the star with side cutters to make sure the tips are not damaged. Printed on a Replicator 2 this support comes away easily. On a 5th Generation MakerBot the support is harder to remove and there may be some stringing of filament. This can easily be cleaned up with a craft knife.   
A great way to top off your Christmas Tree!
